div.p:
I am not quite sure whether my flattering correspon
dents correspondents are in jest or earnest, but at all events, I will
with pleasure satisfy, as far as I am able the curi
osity curiosity they express. I am gratified to find that the
Frankland Family have inspired so much in interest
as to make the readers of their history take the trouble
of enquiring about their wedding apparel. I have
received various letters on the subject but none so
complimentary and so urgent as that I am now
answering...Very fortunately for the three brides
it happened that there was a short time previous
to their marriages a custom house officers sale in
Monmouth of Admiral Tipsey's smuggled goods.
Mrs Hungersford presented to the three brides three
gowns of French cambric purchased at this sale
which were made up in the neatest manner
possible by the best milliner in Monmouth and
trimmed with some of Admiral Tipsey's best satin
lace. The dress maker assured me that no
thing could be more becoming than the set of
the vandyke collars about the necks.
Mrs Hungersfords children provided French white
gloves and French shoes, Mr Cleghorn, at Tipsey's sale,
in which he was right glad he had no concern
bought the very pretty veils of French manufacture
which he presented to the brides Frank put them

on his sisters with so good a grace that Mr Cleghorn begged he would also put on his
daughter's veil, that she might look as well as
the Franklands. Mr Jos Crumpe whose English
blood could not bear the idea of the girls
being Frenchified from top to toe insisted that
at least they might have some thing English
about them and accordingly presented each
with half a dozen pair of such beautiful fine
cotten stockings, as cannot be had for love or
money now a days out of honest old England.
on the same principle he gave htem white chip
hats trimmed with English white ribbon "for
say what you will of French white ribbon, what they
call white is no more white than I am I declare"
Gowns, hats, veils, gloves, shoes, stockings, nothing
wanting but white handkerchiefs, which
old Frankland, who utterly detested shawls begged
his girls would wear and Miss Cleghorn had
also the complaisance to wear one, tho' she had
a fine French shawl, which the Admiral forced
upon her acceptance. I cannot learn that they
had such necklaces, bracelets or baubles of any kind,
but they certainly had prayer books neatly
bound in morocco; the gift of young Mr Jolingsby
so much for the Brides, now for the Bridegrooms
who had first intended to be dressed alike but
Frank objected, "lest it should look like an
house uniform" so James Frankland to the

of the Biographers opinion, was in blue and
sister's Bridegrooms wore brown. All certainly
had Cambric cravats presented by Mr Cleghorn.
Mr Barlow provided each with a handsome
watch, chain and sils. These are all the par
ticulars particulars I have been able to collect after a
most dilligent search, inspecting the accoutre
ments accoutrements of the Frankland family, may I be per
mitted permitted to hold, tho' no questions I have
on that point, that Mrs Hungerford was dressed
in an of Irish Jabbinet, so glossy
that now with not touching it, and who could
presume to touch Mrs Hungerford's dress? could
believe it to be any thing but rich silk or satin.
This admired Jabbinet was presented by Miss E
who has the honour to be descended from a branch
of that family. One other circumstance equally
deserved to be recorded, that whent he young Miss
Hungerfords had distributed handsome wedding
favours, no power or persuasion could prevail
on Mr Jos Crumpe to touch one because he was never
had and by the blessing of Heaven "never would
wear any thing French while he had English
breath in his body". Patty whilst all the company
who using different arguments made him
a favour of English ribbon which he wore with
great satisfaction and sent Patty in return
some choice Irish India sweetmeats for the
